newsitem.title: JAPAN: Asian crude gains on futures, physical markets mum.
newsitem.headline: Asian crude gains on futures, physical markets mum.

text.p: Crude prices firmed marginally in early Asia on Thursday, but largely brushed off a headline-driven futures rally in New York on Wednesday which lifted July WTI values by 27 cents, traders said.
At midday, June cash Brent was notionally assessed at $20.20/20.30, and July Brent at $20.10/20/20. The latter was a touch firmer than London's IPE Wednesday close of $20.12.
Wet markets were slow in waking up from Wednesday's Singapore holiday, with traders reporting no fresh physical deals as of 0300 GMT.
"We're likely to be pretty quiet until next week," said one trader of Gulf grades.
"You might see some June cargoes traded, and there is some Dubai being talked, but not much more," he added.
Trade in July Middle Eastern grades is likely to begin in earnest by early next week, traders said.
Wednesday's bullishness on NYMEX grew out of reports that Turkish forces has staged another incursion across the border of Iraq, with further support seen from an API stock-driven gasoline gain.
But the WTI bull run sputtered in out-of hours ACCESS trade, with July retreating to $21.77 from Wednesday's NYMEX settlement of $21.86.
SIMEX Brent was untraded Thursday as of 0250 GMT, with one offer for July registered at $20.20.
